content.description:
As the name implies. Climb through two roofs with slab in between and after.

Horrible rock at the two cruxes (two roofs) with the first roof being the harder of the two with a potential for a janky looking fall. I ripped a large rock out on the second roof with my foot at what appeared to be the least suspect looking rock but clearly wasn't. You're then treated to 5+ more meters of 5.6 slab climbing for some reason which is lovely for your rope when you lower off. You might think to mitigate this by rappelling but cleaning is extremely awkward due to the fall line being far off from the bolt line. So if, despite all this, you decide to climb this route maybe belay your follower up to clean then both rap off.



Start of the steep section, just to the right of the large slab crack route that turns into a chimney.

Bolts

One of the best routes at the cliff. Crux comes midway, pulling a bulge onto a slabby section. The beta I found was to head slightly left, but due to the proximity of this route with Cadet From Space I'm not entirely sure this is intended. There are holds to the right that look doable but is a bit further of a traverse. Otherwise, heading straight up will require a high left foot with slabby hands, then a transition to the slab itself. 



Last bolted route on the right. Next to Cadet from Space (10c), which climbs the right facing corner. These two climbs are just to the right of the large roof and get a fair amount of shade.

Bolts

Fun and sustained techy slab climb. One awkward clip and an unnecessarily set back anchor (theme for the crag) but otherwise fantastic climb.



Furthest left route at the crag in a corner shared with a 5.7.

Bolts

Not the worst route but the two cruxy sections have fairly bad rock.  I wouldn't call this route harder than 10a personally, simply that the rock makes it feel a lot more committing. First crux comes low with crimpy hands and smeary feet that feel like they could blow at any second.



Climb the right facing corner to the left of activity center and right to the large, unclimbed roofs.

Bolts

Fun corner climb to the right of Bear Hug. Pretty straightforward and well protected.



Second route from the left, right side of the corner. 

Bolts

Climb the obvious chimney with 2 bolts to rambly terrain. The crux comes at a short vertical wall. This climb is as horizontal as it is vertical. Possibly best to rap, but it's long so watch your tails. Watch when you pull your rope as this route still brings down lots of rocks. I watched multiple people have close calls because they weren't paying attention as they pulled, be ready to step left under the roof for cover.



4th bolted line from the left, starts in the very obvious chimney

Bolts

Nice climb but this is far from a Squamish splitter. Typical limestone crack with friable features within, especially where the rock gets loose at the crux. 

FA calls this 5.8 but I would say 5.8+ if not 5.9. Currently the crux has very licheny feet and you're above small gear for at least a body length as the crack gets shallow and flared until the crux moves (placed a #1 here but wouldn't call it bombproof for a big whip, however I did shamelessly hang on it while I sussed things out). Crux takes a 0.75 and a #1, and then a #2 a bit higher. Very fun hand jam sequence. Below that you'd want a 0.3 and above a grey or purple BD cam (which isn't necessary as the moves ease off but if you like stitching things up like me, nice to have.). Didn't find any good nut placements but there surely are some if need be.



Far right of the crag. Finger sized crack that gets shallow then widens up to hands where it gets steep.

Gear with rings at anchor.

Crux right at the start. A few burly moves on meh rock leads to much easier climbing (one slightly awkward section traversing to a ledge but otherwise much easier). FA calls this 10a. Felt at least 10b to me, but I don't climb steep stuff often. Another route that feels like a few meters of 5.7 climbing was added at the expense of your rope.



3rd bolted line from the left. 

Bolts

Sunny area out of town. Good mix of climbs from 5.7 - 5.10+. Detailed info and topos available on Northern Exposure website by Francois Laplante (who also established most climbs here with friends). Most climbs are low angle on sharp rock with anchors set far back, so expect lowering here to put some wear on your rope.
